quoteFirst: So they are busy at work till at
quoteLast: a bugle goes for all to go down into the mess-room, where they range themselves at their places for breakfast.
title:
Little Folks (September 1884)
A Magazine for the Young
author: Various

quoteFirst: Wednesday, 15th May, Lawson Creek. Started at
quoteLast: ; went a mile west to clear the stones; changed course to 340 degrees. At 2.45 p.m. changed again to 45 degrees. Camped at 4.15. The first twelve miles is poor country, being on the top of stony rises, with eucalypti, grass, and scrubs.
title:
Explorations in Australia
The Journals of John McDouall Stuart During the Years 1858, 1859, 1860, 1861, and 1862, When He Fixed the Centre of the Continent and Successfully Crossed It from Sea to Sea
author: Stuart, John McDouall, 1815-1866

quoteFirst: As soon as she was seen from the _Bloodhound_, Captain Jones ordered that the guns of the _Bloodhound's_ gunboats should open a deliberate flanking fire on the west part of the enemy's defences; and he then sent a boat under Mr Bullen, his clerk, who was acting as his aide-de-camp, to point out to Captain Lyster the position in which he wished the _Teazer_ to be anchored.  At
quoteLast: , the _Teazer_ having anchored, Captain Jones pulled on board her, to consult further with Captain Lyster on the plan of proceeding.  The rocket-boats were then ordered to take up a position to the northward of the _Bloodhound_.
title: Our Sailors: Gallant Deeds of the British Navy during Victoria's Reign
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880

quoteLast: on Thursday, March the 9th, and motored until noon. Then got the canvas on her. Light airs: E.; N.N.E.; N.; S.S.E.; S.E.b.E. between noon and midnight. Made good 17½ miles.
title: The mystery of Easter island: the story of an expedition
author: Routledge, Katherine, 1866-1935

quoteLast: Ferrero's four thousand three hundred negroes rushed over and reached the right flank of the Seventeenth. This horde of barbarians added greatly to the thousands of white men that packed themselves to the safe side of the breastworks.
title:
History of Kershaw's Brigade
With Complete Roll of Companies, Biographical Sketches, Incidents, Anecdotes, etc.
author: Dickert, D. A. (David Augustus), 1844-1917

quoteFirst: As soon as the deployment was completed, the Scots Guards were ordered to advance at once, swing round their right, and take the enemy in flank. Lieut.-Colonel Pulteney with two companies and a machine gun was pushing round to the right, to carry out the turning movement, when, at about
quoteLast: he came under a sudden and violent fire from the enemy concealed in the low bushes of the Riet or in the trenches on its left bank. The companies suffered considerably; and of the men forming the detachment with the Maxim all were killed or wounded by a well-concealed pom-pom.
title:
History of the War in South Africa 1899-1902 v. 1 (of 4)
Compiled by Direction of His Majesty's Government
author: Great Britain. War Office; Maurice, John Frederick, 1841-1912 [Compiler]

quoteFirst: Not a breath of wind this morning. Our course as seen from a hill close by last night will be about east-south-east for some distance this morning. Started at
quoteLast: ; at three and a quarter miles came to a barrier right across from range to range, and after considerable detention succeeded in finding a road on our left round the range that the barriers form from; at four miles came to where one branch (the largest) comes from the south with plenty of water in its bed in the stone and rocks; the other branch is considerably to the east so will try it, although it does not at all look a watery branch but is much more in the direction I want to go.
title: McKinlay's Journal of Exploration in the Interior of Australia
author: McKinlay, John, 1819-1872

quoteFirst: The commandant, Major (now Colonel) de Buvignes, and I set out for a stroll along the sands to the west. The morning was close and cloudy: what little breeze there was came from the south-west, under a leaden sky and over a leaden sea. At
quoteLast: , as we were returning from the rocks about three-quarters of a mile off, there was a sudden rambling like a distant thunder-clap; the sands seemed to wave up and down as a shaken carpet, and we both staggered forwards. Others described the movement as rising and falling like the waters of a lagoon.
title: To The Gold Coast for Gold: A Personal Narrative. Vol. II
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890; Cameron, Verney Lovett, 1844-1894

quoteFirst: It will be an evening star, though appearing but a short time after sunset each day. On the 1st it rises at
quoteLast: , and sets at 5:20 p. m.; on the 16th rises at 7:51 a. m., sets at 5:21 p. m.; on the 30th rises at 7:29 a. m., sets at 5:21 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, January 1885, No. 4
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteLast: , and marched twenty-six miles, and camped at the Kárez Amánullah. The morning air was sharp, and, by the thermometer, showed nine degrees of frost.
title: From the Indus to the Tigris
author: Bellew, H. W. (Henry Walter), 1834-1892

quoteFirst: I never in so short a time saw an animal fall away so much. At 7 a.m. struck the tracks of our horses and camels as we returned from Cadhibaerri and followed them to camp. They led a little more to the south than my course, as I now find that would take me out on the lake camp about two miles north of camp. At about
quoteLast: got to camp, the horse very seedy and myself not feeling very well. Some natives visited the camp during my absence and I now see some on the opposite side of lake. I sent for one to endeavour to get some information from him.
title: McKinlay's Journal of Exploration in the Interior of Australia
author: McKinlay, John, 1819-1872

quoteFirst: In the present instance I had been up the night before till about half-past twelve, and consequently when I was called I fell asleep again, and was thunderstruck to find on waking that it was
quoteLast: . I have had no imposition, nor heard anything about it. It is rather vexatious to have happened so soon, as I had intended never to be late.

quoteFirst: The whole valley quickly learned that he had not come back with his second load of wood by eight o’clock and that she was asking them all if they knew anything about it. In the space of twenty minutes with the telephone she had made him ridiculous throughout the precinct; and then at
quoteLast: , while she was ringing up her friend Mrs. Sedlaw for the second time, in came Jimsy.
